question: The colonel. Where's the colonel? We know where Ali la Pointe is. One of them "spoke" ...
answer: C'mon, let him breathe!

question: It seems so. We'll go see. Give him a little coffee.
answer: Hey Marc, you made him talk?

question: Go away!
answer: Men have two faces

question: And they sent you!
answer: Sure, something wrong with that? Take it. Everything's written here.

question: Wait! Come here ... Come. Can you read?
answer: Sure ...

question: Read it.
answer: Here?

question: Here. Not Medjebri? Okay ... Don't move! Look at him. You're not giving any orders now! Your hands are up, eh! Do you see him, brothers? Our masters aren't very special, are they? Bastard! ... Bitch! Tell me what this joke is all about.
answer: Let's move now or they'll catch us.

question: I want to know who sent me that letter. What's his name?
answer: He's waiting for you!

question: Where?
answer: We're going there ... if you don't get us arrested first.

question: Move ... go ahead. I'll follow you.
answer: You could have been a spy. We had to put you to the test.

question: With an unloaded pistol?
answer: I'll explain. Let's suppose you were a spy. In prison, when the NLF contacts you, you pretend to support the revolution, and then the French help you to escape ...

question: Sure. By shooting at me.
answer: Even that could be a trick. You escape, then show up at the address which the brothers in prison gave to you, and so you are able to contact me ...

question: I don't even know your name yet ...
answer: My name is Kader, Ali ... Saari Kader ... In other words, in order to join the organization, you had to undergo a test. I could have told you to murder the barman, but he's an Algerian ... and the police would let you kill him, even though he is one of theirs. By obeying such an order, you still could have been a double agent. And that's why I told you to kill the French policeman

question: But I haven't shot him.
answer: You weren't able to. But what's important is that you tried.

question: What's important for me is that you let me risk my life for nothing.
answer: C'mon ... you're exaggerating. The orders were to shoot him in the back.

question: I don't do that kind of thing.
answer: Then don't complain.

question: You still haven't told me why you didn't let me kill him.
answer: Because we aren't ready yet for the French. Before attacking, we must have safe places from which to depart and find refuge. Of course, there is the Casbah. But even the Casbah isn't safe yet. There are too many drunks, pushers, whores, addicts, spies ... people who talk too much ... people who are ready to sell themselves, undecided people. We must either convince them or eliminate them. We must think of ourselves first. We must clean out the Casbah first. Only then will we be able to deal with the French. Do you understand, Ali?

question: And how many are we?
answer: Not enough.

question: Wake up! Have you seen Hacene le Bonois? Seen Hacene le Bonois? Tell him I'm looking for him ... Is Hacene le Bonois here? I want to see him. If he shows up, tell him that I'm around.
answer: Ali, my son ... Where have you been hiding?

question: Don't move! Hands still.
answer: You know I never carry weapons ...

question: I know.
answer: You afraid of these ...?

question: Don't move, Hacene.
answer: Why are you afraid? We've always been friends. One might even say that I brought you up ... Isn't it true, Ali?

question: It's true.
answer: What's happened to you?

question: The NLF has condemned you to death.
answer: Ah, so its come to this ... I'm dying of laughter! Ha ... ha ... ha ... How much are they paying you?

question: They're not paying me anything. They've already warned you twice; this is the last warning. Decide.
answer: What ... What must I decide?

question: You've got to change occupations, Hacene. Right away!
answer: Okay, you convince me.

question: Are you mad, touching one of their women? Go on, go on, alright ... Go ahead, keep moving! What are you doing here? Where are you going?
answer: No, no, no, no, ... me no ... Viva France ...

question: Get out, go on, outside ... Get out of the way! Go away ...
answer: Sir ... sir ... sir ...

question: What's your name?
answer: Sir ... sir ... sir ...

question: What's your name?
answer: Lardjane Boualem, sir ...

question: Guilty
answer: Seven assaults, three dead. Here, one for the Commissioner ... the press offices ... the archives ... and one for you, sir.

question: Good, thank you, Corbiere... . See you tomorrow.
answer: Good evening, sir.

question: Tell me ... Where is this rue de Thbes?
answer: Rue de Thbes? In the Upper Casbah, I think ...

question: All right. See you tomorrow, Corbiere.
answer: Good evening, sir.

question: Good evening ...
answer: Good evening ... Can we pass?

question: It's too late. No one is allowed to enter the Casbah at this hour. It's impossible.
answer: But it's not even midnight yet!

question: It's ten minutes past midnight. Curfew begins at midnight.
answer: Please, we just want to take a short ride. A friend of mine has never seen the Casbah.

question: Let's go, Henry.
answer: Thank you. Good evening. This way?

question: Yes, it's the first intersection ... or the second.
answer: Right or left?

question: Try going to the right.
answer: What number is it?

question: Eight. It does matter. Go back, Henry. Let's go to number eight.
answer: How long do you want the timing device?

question: Kader says to stop them! He says we've got to stop them!
answer: Where's Kader?

question: With the others. They are trying to stop the people.
answer: Go away.

question: I've come to take the package ...
answer: I'd like to search you, Miss ...

question: Where?
answer: Not here. There's too many people.

question: But you don't understand. I was saying that there's nothing to search.
answer: That's what you think!

question: "Following a lengthy discussion, the General Assembly of the United Nations has decided its agenda for the forthcoming debates: "Mr. Raymond Lefevre, Inspector General of the Administration, has presided over a meeting in which important decisions have been taken with the aim of securing public order and the protection of persons and their property. In particular, it has been decided to recall the 'Tenth' Division of paratroopers to Algiers that, until now, has been employed in the antiguerrilla operations on the Cabiro plateau. The Commander General of the Tenth Division will assume responsibility for the maintenance of order in Algiers, and will have at his disposal in order to achieve this goal, all civil and military means provided for the defense of the zone."
answer: 3rd Regiment! Attention  droite ... Droite!

question: Family name
answer: The result is that in the last two months, they have reached an average of 4.2 assaults per day, including aggression against individuals, and the explosions. Of course, the conditions of the problem are as usual Draw it down there too ... He is an adversary who shifts his position above and below the surface with highly commendable revolutionary methods and original tactics. ... He is an anonymous and unrecognizable enemy who mingles with thousands of others who resemble him. We find him everywhere Go ahead, Martin. Here is some film taken by the police. The cameras were hidden at the Casbah exits. They thought these films might be useful, and in fact they are useful in demonstrating the usefulness of certain methods. Or, at least, their inadequacy. I chose these films because they were shot in the hours preceding some recent terroristic assaults. And so, among all these Arabs, men and women, there are the ones responsible. But which ones are they? How can we recognize them? Controlling documents is ridiculous Note the intuition of the cameraman. He realized that in that box, there had to be something of interest, and he paused to focus it. Maybe the bomb was hidden right there, in a double bottom. Who knows? We'll never know. That's enough, Martin ... We must start again from scratch. The only information that we have concerns the structure of the organization. And we shall begin from that ... It is a pyramid-like organization divided into a series of sectors. At the top of the pyramid is their General Staff. The military commander responsible for the executive body finds the right man and nominates him to responsibility for a sector Now number two and number three choose, in their turn, two men each ... number four and five, and so on ... The reason for this geometry is so that every militant will know only three members in the entire organization To know them means to eliminate them. Consequently, the military aspect is secondary to the police method. I know we are not fond of this word, but it is the only word that indicates exactly the type of work that we must perform. We must make the necessary investigations in order to proceed from one vertex to another in the entire pyramid. The reason for this work is information. The method is interrogation. And interrogation becomes a method when conducted in a manner so as to always obtain a result, or rather, an answer. In practice, demonstrating a false humanitarianism only leads to the ridiculous and to impotence. I am certain that all the units will understand and react accordingly. However, success does not depend solely on us. We need to have the Casbah at our disposal. We must sift through it ... and interrogate everyone. And here is where we find ourselves hindered by a conspiracy of laws and regulations that continue to be operative, as if Algiers were a holiday resort and not a battleground. We have requested a carte blanche. But it is very difficult to obtain. Therefore, it is necessary to find an excuse to legitimize our intervention, and make it possible. It is necessary to create it ourselves -- this excuse. Unless our adversaries will think of it themselves, which seems to be what they are doing.

question: "To all militants! After two years of hard struggle in the mountains and city, the Algerian people have obtained a great victory. The UN Assembly has placed the Algerian question in its forthcoming agenda. The discussion will begin on Monday, January 28. Starting Monday, for a duration of eight days, the NLF is calling a general strike. For the duration of this period, all forms of armed action or attempts at such are suspended. We are requesting that all militants mobilize for the strike's organization and success." "Algerian brothers! A great hope has arisen for us. The world is watching us. The next few days may be decisive for our future and our freedom. The colonial powers will attempt to demonstrate to the UN that the NFL does not represent the will of our people. Our response will be unanimous support of the general strike." "During the eight days of the strike, do not frequent the European city, or leave the Casbah. Provide lodgings in your homes for the poor, the beggars, the brothers who do not have homes. Store provisions of food and water for eight days!"
answer: No one is leaving, eh?

question: No one is leaving, eh?
answer: No. They continue to enter, the rats.

question: Rats in a trap, we hope ...
answer: But do you believe that the strike will be widespread?

question: Without a doubt.
answer: Mathieu! Mathieu, a name ...

question: A name?
answer: Yes, a name for the operation.

question: Champagne ... All right?
answer: Champagne ... Champagne. Operation Champagne, yes, alright.

question: They are beggars and unemployed, homeless. We have organized things in such a way that during the strike they will be guests of other families who have homes and will provide shelter in the event of possible reprisals ... But I didn't know that they would be brought to this house too. It is a mistake.
answer: Why?

question: Because you are here too. It would be better for you to move to another house.
answer: All right ... You're the one who must decide.

question: No, if I were the one to decide, you wouldn't be in Algiers now.
answer: Why? Isn't it wise?

question: It isn't wise. Ali, you must accompany Ben M'Hidi to the Maison des Arbres.
answer: Why? Isn't he sleeping here?

question: No, it's better if he doesn't. The house is filled with new people.
answer: Here's another one ready. What a hideout! It really looks like a wall. I'll dirty it a bit, and it's perfect. Want to give a look inside?

question: But it's he who won't be safe with me ...
answer: Here it is ... we've arrived ...

question: Not yet ...
answer: Be careful now. Unless you know how it works, it's better if you sit on the plank and move forward like this ...

question: Let's try ... It's good nobody is following us ...
answer: It's a question of habit ... It's better if I go first, to make sure everything's okay ... Everything's okay ... They're waiting for you ...

question: What do you think of the strike, Ali?
answer: I think it'll be a success ...

question: Yes, I think so too ... It's been organized well ... But what will the French do?
answer: It's clear. They'll do everything possible to make it fail.

question: No, they'll do even more. We've given them the opportunity to do a lot more ... Do you understand what I mean? Starting tomorrow, they won't be groping in the dark any more; every shop and every worker who strikes will be a known enemy, a self-confessed criminal ... And they will be able to pass to the offensive. Have you thought of this?
answer: No ...

question: But Kader told me that you weren't in favor of the strike.
answer: No, and neither were my men.

question: Why?
answer: Because they told us that we mustn't use weapons, now, when the time is right.

question: That's true ... Wars aren't won with terrorism, neither wars nor revolutions. Terrorism is a beginning but afterward, all the people must act ... This is the reason for the strike, and its necessity
answer: To show them to the UN, right?

question: Yes ... yes. The problem also involves the UN. I don't know what it's worth, but this way, we'll give the UN the possibility of evaluating our strength. Do you know something Ali? Starting a revolution is hard, and it's even harder to continue it. Winning is hardest of all. But only afterward, when we have won, will the real hardships begin. Anyway, there's still a lot to be done ... you aren't already tired, Ali, are you?
answer: No!

question: Insurrection.
answer: But the NLF has always spoken of a strike as a demonstration ...

question: And you believe the NLF?
answer: They seemed to be plausible this time. A general strike is a good argument for the

question: It is an inevitable stage in revolutionary war; from terrorism, one passes to insurrection ... as from open guerrilla warfare one passes to real war, the latter being the determining factor ...
answer: Dien Bien Phu?

question: Exactly. In Indochina, they won.
answer: And here?

question: Go ahead! C'mon ... Repeat everything from the beginning, and then we'll let you go. Name ...
answer: Sid Ahmed.

question: Second name.
answer: Sail.

question: Which "district" do you belong to?
answer: Second district ...

question: Second district ... Explain better ...
answer: Second district, Casbah, West Algiers.

question: What "group"?
answer: Third group.

question: Third group. What's your assignment?
answer: Uh ... responsible for the sixth section.

question: You can come out. Thank God. There were so many this time, about ten.
answer: Paratroopers?

question: Yes.
answer: What do you think? Did they come here on purpose or by accident?

question: It's better to split up, to increase our chances. We must change hiding places, and change them continually ... In the meantime, we must make new contacts, replace our arrested brothers, reorganize our sections--
answer: Yes, but we must also show them that we still exist.

question: Of course. As soon as possible.
answer: No, immediately. The people are demoralized. Leave this to me ...

question: The successes obtained are the results of those methods. One presupposes the other and vice versa.
answer: Excuse me, colonel. I have the impression that perhaps due to excessive prudence ... my colleagues continue to ask the same allusive questions, to which you can only respond in an allusive manner. I think it would be better to call things by their right names; if one means torture, then one should call it torture.

question: I understand. What's your question?
answer: The questions have already been asked. I would only like some precise answers, that's all ...

question: Let's try to be precise then. The word "torture" does not appear in our orders. We have always spoken of interrogation as the only valid method in a police operation directed against unknown enemies. As for the NLF, they request that their members, in the event of capture, should maintain silence for twenty-four hours, and then, they may talk. Thus, the organization has already had the time necessary to render useless any information furnished ... What type of interrogation should we choose? ... the one the courts use for a crime of homicide which drags on for months?
answer: The law is often inconvenient, colonel ...

question: Now is not the time for heroes. Give me the megaphone. Ramel ... Si Mourad ... use your heads. If you go on like this, I wouldn't want to be in your place when you are captured ... Because you will be captured in the end, and you know it too. Surrender! If you do it immediately, I promise that you will not be harmed and you will have a fair trial. Can you hear me?
answer: Who is speaking?

question: Mathieu. Colonel Mathieu.
answer: We don't trust you, colonel. Come forward, show yourself.

question: I don't trust you either. First stand up so I can see you, and keep your hands still and well in sight.
answer: Okay. But we want your promise for a fair trial in writing. Give us a written statement, Mathieu, and then we'll surrender.

question: How can I give you this statement?
answer: We'll lower a basket from the window ...

question: Okay, I'll make the statement in writing ...
answer: A newspaper too, or a piece of paper ... Are you ready, colonel?

question: Which one of you is Fathia? Is it you? Go up the stairs, and tell Kader that if they don't surrender, we'll blow up everything ... Do you understand? Try to convince him, if you care about your house ... Wait a minute ... Do you want to get killed? Kader, look. Fathia is coming ... I wouldn't shoot ... Go on ...
answer: Okay ... You can tell the colonel to blow up whatever he likes. Go on, now.

question: Return to where the others are. Prepare the plastic. It should be placed on the ceiling of the stairway under the hiding place ... a long fuse rolled up ... Take cover ... keep shooting while you are working. Quickly! Clear the house ... Bring them outside, then check the rooms again ... Hurry up!
answer: It doesn't do any good to die like this ... it doesn't help anybody ... Mathieu! If you give your word that you won't touch any of the other people in the house, we'll come out.

question: If you had let me blow you up, you would have disappointed me ...
answer: Why?

question: For many months, I've had your photo on my desk together with a dozen or so reports on you ... And naturally, I am under the illusion that I know you somewhat. You never seemed the type, Kader, inclined to performing useless actions.
answer: You seem to be very satisfied to have taken me alive ...

question: Of course I am.
answer: That proves that I was wrong. Evidently I credited you with an advantage greater than I should have.

question: No. Let's just say that you've given me the satisfaction to have guessed correctly. But from the technical point of view, it isn't possible to speak of advantages. By now the game is over. The NLF has been defeated. What is she saying?
answer: She says that Ali is still in the Casbah.

question: Then the beach is okay, Ali.
answer: We need two more, the biggest ones.

question: And the others?
answer: The others ... let's wait and see.

question: I've looked, Ali, even where I work. Nothing. The ones who have not been arrested have left Algiers and gone into the mountains ... And the others don't want to hear any more about it ... they're afraid ...
answer: Can't you go any faster?

question: Yes, sure ... here. If we don't find any others ... should we call it off? We can't plant all of them by ourselves ...
answer: You don't have to plant anything. You only have to carry them, that's all. C'mon, hurry. Go to sleep. Tomorrow we four have a lot of work to do Because we can't find anyone else, Sadek will bring us there in the truck. You get out first and plant the bomb where I tell you ... then return here quickly. But be careful that no one is following you. Then Hassiba will get out, and after her, Mahmoud. Then I will plant the ones that are left. They'll know that we're still strong ... you can be sure of that. Omar, Omar. C'mon, wake up. Hurry, little one. Today you're going to see fireworks. Yes. Hassiba ...

question: You don't have to plant anything. You only have to carry them, that's all. C'mon, hurry. Go to sleep. Tomorrow we four have a lot of work to do Because we can't find anyone else, Sadek will bring us there in the truck. You get out first and plant the bomb where I tell you ... then return here quickly. But be careful that no one is following you. Then Hassiba will get out, and after her, Mahmoud. Then I will plant the ones that are left. They'll know that we're still strong ... you can be sure of that. Omar, Omar. C'mon, wake up. Hurry, little one. Today you're going to see fireworks. Yes. Hassiba ...
answer: I'm ready.

question: Me too. But I don't think it was Sadek. Otherwise he'd be here by now.
answer: How is your wife now?

question: Here?
answer: Everything ready?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: He hasn't answered?

question: No, sir. Total silence.
answer: I thought so. It was obvious. Ali ... Ali la Pointe ... You're going to be blown up. Let the others come out, at least the child. We'll let him off with reformatory school ... Why do you want to make him die? Let's go ...

question: And so the tapeworm no longer has a head. Are you satisfied, Mathieu? In Algiers everything should be over.
answer: Yes, I believe there won't be any more talk of the NLF for some time.

question: Let's hope forever.
answer: Bah, for that matter, Algeria isn't the only country in the world ...
